thread.title: New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite
thread.title_full: New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite

title: New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite Five former BCS computer formulas identify five different teams as No. 1 in the latest College Football Computer Rankings. Post to Facebook New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite Five former BCS computer formulas identify five different teams as No. 1 in the latest College Football Computer Rankings. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1RSbJua Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 10 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs New No. 1 team takes over in Computer Composite Daniel Uthman , USA TODAY Sports 1:30 p.m. EDT October 19, 2015 LSU running back Derrius Guice (5) and defensive end Lewis Neal (92) celebrate after the Tigers' 35-28 win vs. Florida. (Photo: Crystal LoGiudice, USA TODAY Spor) 450 CONNECT 52 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 10 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
After five weeks of stability at the top spot in the College Football Computer Composite rankings, the former BCS computers have a new No. 1 team for the second consecutive week. 
LSU, on the strength of its win Saturday against previously undefeated Florida, jumped 10 spots to No. 1. The Tigers are the first team in the two-year history of the CFCC to make a double-digit jump to No. 1. 
The geometric mean difference between LSU and No. 2 Utah is just 0.14 of a place, with Ohio State close behind at No. 3. 
Last week's No. 1, TCU, slid five spots to No. 6 after a tougher-than-expected win a Iowa State. Follow the road to the 2015 College Football Playoff at The Football Four , our home to rate and debate the nation's best. 
For the second consecutive week, none of the five formulas that combine into the CFCC had the same No. 1 team. Michigan State is No. 1 in Richard Billingsley 's rankings, Utah is No. 1 in Wes Colley 's rankings, Baylor is No. 1 in Ken Massey 's rankings, Alabama is No. 1 in Jeff Sagarin 's rankings, and LSU is No. 1 in Peter Wolfe 's rankings. 
LSU was seventh and 10th, respectively, in Massey and Sagarin's rankings — the only two of the five formulas that factor in margin of victory — but was ranked second by Billingsley and Colley. 
Utah State jumped 23 spots to No. 40 after forcing eight turnovers in a 52-26 win Saturday against Boise State. Kansas State, which lost 55-0 to Oklahoma on Saturday, was this week's biggest decliner, falling 25 spots. 
The College Football Computer Composite combines five of the computer formulas used in the former Bowl Championship Series standings to remove the human element from college football rankings. It is compiled by taking the geometric mean of rankings formulated by Billingsley, Colley, Massey, Sagarin and Wolfe. Among the metrics feeding the CFCC are wins and losses, strength of schedule, home-field advantage, recency of game and, in Massey and Sagarin's case, margin of victory. 
Updated CFCC rankings are published each week during the season on FootballFour.com . The complete ranking of all 128 FBS teams is below. 450 CONNECT 52 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 10 COMMENT EMAIL MORE TOP VIDEOS
